image.altText: A smiling elderly woman with short, white hair.

items.synopsis: The civil matter has been listed under Clare Nowland's name. The 95-year-old died in hospital earlier this year after falling and hitting her head following the alleged incident with a police officer.

title.children: Family of great-grandmother who died after allegedly being tasered by police sues NSW

image.altText: A mine site in bushland, as seen from above.

title.children: 'Absolutely emotional': Sydney man freed from Vietnam prison and returned to Australia

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

title.children: Three brothers own the NZ volcano that killed 17 Australians. Today their trial begins

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair, wearing a pinstripe jacket, sits in the kitchen of a house.

title.children: It took Shay almost a month to find a rental. Now it might be making her sick

image.altText: a drone shot of a town nestled between red rock ranges

items.synopsis: Police in Kununurra faced significant public unrest over the weekend, with rocks thrown at officers during the incident.

title.children: Kimberley police pushed to limit by 12-hour brawl involving more than 80 people

image.altText: A woman with black hair looks sternly at cameras during a press conference

items.synopsis: Ms Fyles says the reintroduction of crocodile culling should be considered following an attack at a popular tourist swimming spot.

title.children: 'It's time': NT chief minister says crocodile culling should be considered following attack

image.altText: A man with brown hair wearing a denim jacket smiles

items.synopsis: A cluster of drowning deaths in the Canberra region reveal a lack of danger awareness around rivers, Coroner Paula Russell says.

title.children: Four ACT riverside outings turned tragic within 16 months. A coroner says the victims didn't know the dangers

title.children: Did you reclaim the bond from your last rental? More than 114,000 are currently unclaimed in Queensland

image.altText: Smoking and infertility risks

items.synopsis: Fertility experts say most people don't know smoking increases the risk of infertility in both men and women. Sarah says if more smokers were aware, it could help them quit.

title.children: Many women 'unaware' of impacts smoking could have on fertility, experts say

image.altText: Courtney Barnett stands in a blue raincoat lifting her right hand against a clear blue sky with lens flare

title.children: 'I learnt a lot about myself' — Courtney Barnett is ending Milk! Records with a new instrumental album and positive outlook

items.synopsis: A WA Police officer faces court accused of committing a string of child sex offences against a teenage girl between 2009 and 2012, starting when she was aged 13.

image.altText: Madonna, sitting during an awards show, looks in the distance as blue light dims the hall.

items.synopsis: The 64-year-old singer has postponed her entire North American tour and is now focusing on "getting stronger".

title.children: Madonna makes first public statement after spending multiple days in intensive care

items.synopsis: The cost to make a flat white jumped by nearly one-fifth in two years, as the cafe industry faces cost of living pressures.

title.children: Coffee culture an early casualty of cost-of-living crisis

title.children: Here’s a way to avoid tears when cutting onions

image.altText: A woman holding her baby in her arms.

items.synopsis: For mothers with drug or alcohol dependence, one of the biggest barriers to seeking help at a residential rehab is who will look after their children while they get treatment.

title.children: This mum went into rehab. She brought her baby with her

image.altText: a photo of a man sitting at a small table in a caravan

items.synopsis: Residents are wondering where they will go, after they were asked to leave their homes at a Bendigo caravan park with just two weeks' notice.

title.children: Permanent residents of caravan park given weeks to find new homes after developer buys property

image.altText: Boxes of feta cheese on the production line with "Protected Designation of Origin" written on the labels.

items.synopsis: The future of Australian producers using terms like prosecco and feta hangs in the balance as trade talks with the European Union over a deal that could be worth $100 billion reach a critical moment.

title.children: Australia could keep prosecco and feta and walk away from EU trade talks

image.altText: A mi-shot of Fiona Stanley wearing a red jacket speaking into a microphone against a black backdrop at an indoor forum.

items.synopsis: Former Australian of the Year Fiona Stanley says the Indigenous community's level of input in the health response to the pandemic helped limit case numbers, calling it the "best example" of why a Voice to Parliament will make such a difference.

title.children: Fiona Stanley says Aboriginal response to COVID 'the best example' of why Voice will make a difference

title.children: ASX rebounds from four-day losing streak

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Weak economic data from our largest trading partner China has led to a big fall in iron ore prices (Australia's biggest export to China). The spot price for the steelmaking material (62% iron) dropped to just over $US105 / tonne, its lowest level since June 1. Here's what Commonwealth Bank commodities analyst Vivek Dhar wrote in his latest note to clients: "The demand concerns in China were highlighted by Rio Tinto’s chairman Dominic Barton, when he noted ‘there is a big real estate issue” in China. His comments underscore a deteriorating property sector that accounts for 35 - 40% of China’s steel demand. "A number of property related indicators have turned south. New home price growth has begun to slow after peaking in March 2023. Property investment and property sales (in square metres) has started to contract sharply, falling 22%/yr and 20%/yr respectively in May. "The most relevant indicator for steel demand and therefore the most important for iron ore prices is the drop off in China’s newly constructed floor space. "This reflects the start of the construction process and where steel is mostly used. After dropping ~39%/yr in 2022, China’s newly constructed floor space has declined another ~23%/yr in the first five months of 2023." He also said the surprise slowdown in China’s consumer price index (CPI) to 0% in June highlights broader concerns for China’s economy: "These concerns only increase the likelihood of policy support. And with Politburo’s semi annual economic conference due later this month, we expect policymakers will announce some support for the Chinese economy. "The composition of the policy support will be crucial. Our expectation is that any policy support will be limited, particularly with China only targeting economic growth of 5% this year after growing only 3% in 2022. "Since the early 1970s, China’s economy has lifted at least 7.5% after growing 3% or less the preceding year. "Solving the issues of the property sector will be tricky given confidence and demand are so subdued following the fallout from property developer defaults and falling new home prices through 2022. "As a result we think any support for the property sector will need to be longer and stronger than previous policies. Any stabilisation will therefore be more realistically realised next year."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iron ore prices drop to five-week low

children.content: Weak economic data from our largest trading partner China has led to a big fall in iron ore prices (Australia's biggest export to China).
The spot price for the steelmaking material (62% iron) dropped to just over $US105 / tonne, its lowest level since June 1.
Here's what Commonwealth Bank commodities analyst Vivek Dhar wrote in his latest note to clients:

"The demand concerns in China were highlighted by Rio Tinto’s chairman Dominic Barton, when he noted ‘there is a big real estate issue” in China. His comments underscore a deteriorating property sector that accounts for 35 - 40% of China’s steel demand.

"A number of property related indicators have turned south. New home price growth has begun to slow after peaking in March 2023. Property investment and property sales (in square metres) has started to contract sharply, falling 22%/yr and 20%/yr respectively in May.
"The most relevant indicator for steel demand and therefore the most important for iron ore prices is the drop off in China’s newly constructed floor space.

"This reflects the start of the construction process and where steel is mostly used. After dropping ~39%/yr in 2022, China’s newly constructed floor space has declined another ~23%/yr in the first five months of 2023."
He also said the surprise slowdown in China’s consumer price index (CPI) to 0% in June highlights broader concerns for China’s economy:

"These concerns only increase the likelihood of policy support. And with Politburo’s semi annual economic conference due later this month, we expect policymakers will announce some support for the Chinese economy.

"The composition of the policy support will be crucial. Our expectation is that any policy support will be limited, particularly with China only targeting economic growth of 5% this year after growing only 3% in 2022.
"Since the early 1970s, China’s economy has lifted at least 7.5% after growing 3% or less the preceding year.
"Solving the issues of the property sector will be tricky given confidence and demand are so subdued following the fallout from property developer defaults and falling new home prices through 2022.
"As a result we think any support for the property sector will need to be longer and stronger than previous policies. Any stabilisation will therefore be more realistically realised next year."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have risen sharply, lifted by mining and gold stocks. The ASX 200 gained 1% to 7,071 points, by 12:30pm AEST. The benchmark stock index is on track to snap a four-day losing streak, with all major sub-indices in positive territory. The interest-rate sensitive financial sector advanced 1%, with the "big four" banks gaining between 0.5% and 1.4%. Meanwhile, traders awaited further economic stimulus from China - Australia's biggest trading partner - after data showed a slowing momentum in economic recovery with consumer spending also impacted. Mining giants BHP, Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals rose over 1% each. Gold stocks gained 2.2% in their best day since July 3, with sector-majors Northern Star Resources and Newcrest Mining climbing 1.8% and 1.4%, respectively. Bellevue Gold, Capricorn Metals and De Grey Mining topped the ASX 200 chart with each surging above 5%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX recovers, after dropping for four straight days

children.content: Australian shares have risen sharply, lifted by mining and gold stocks.
The ASX 200 gained 1% to 7,071 points, by 12:30pm AEST.
The benchmark stock index is on track to snap a four-day losing streak, with all major sub-indices in positive territory.
The interest-rate sensitive financial sector advanced 1%, with the "big four" banks gaining between 0.5% and 1.4%.
Meanwhile, traders awaited further economic stimulus from China - Australia's biggest trading partner - after data showed a slowing momentum in economic recovery with consumer spending also impacted.
Mining giants BHP, Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals rose over 1% each.
Gold stocks gained 2.2% in their best day since July 3, with sector-majors Northern Star Resources and Newcrest Mining climbing 1.8% and 1.4%, respectively.
Bellevue Gold, Capricorn Metals and De Grey Mining topped the ASX 200 chart with each surging above 5%.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian consumer sentiment rebounded in July as inflation cooled a little and the Reserve Bank skipped a rise in interest rates, though worries about finances were still present. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment rose 2.7% in July to 81.3 points, the biggest gain since April when rates were also kept on hold. However, any score below 100 points means the pessimists outnumbered optimists. The survey's measure of family finances compared to a year ago remained gloomy with a fall of 4.9%, reflecting cost of living pressures. "The key message is that sentiment is probably not going to stage a sustained lift from current deeply pessimistic levels until inflation is much lower and interest rates are firmly on hold," said Westpac chief economist Bill Evans. The RBA held rates steady at 4.1% last week, in the middle of the survey period, but warned that it might have to hike again to bring inflation to heel. Monthly inflation data for May showed a welcome slowdown to 5.6%, but core price measures remained stubbornly high. In a positive sign for demand, the survey's measure of whether it was a good time to buy a major household item rose 3.1% in July, while its index buying dwellings jumped 6.2%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer sentiment recovers, but inflation continues to weigh on optimism: Westpac survey

children.content: Australian consumer sentiment rebounded in July as inflation cooled a little and the Reserve Bank skipped a rise in interest rates, though worries about finances were still present.
The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment rose 2.7% in July to 81.3 points, the biggest gain since April when rates were also kept on hold.
However, any score below 100 points means the pessimists outnumbered optimists.
The survey's measure of family finances compared to a year ago remained gloomy with a fall of 4.9%, reflecting cost of living pressures.

"The key message is that sentiment is probably not going to stage a sustained lift from current deeply pessimistic levels until inflation is much lower and interest rates are firmly on hold," said Westpac chief economist Bill Evans.
The RBA held rates steady at 4.1% last week, in the middle of the survey period, but warned that it might have to hike again to bring inflation to heel.
Monthly inflation data for May showed a welcome slowdown to 5.6%, but core price measures remained stubbornly high.
In a positive sign for demand, the survey's measure of whether it was a good time to buy a major household item rose 3.1% in July, while its index buying dwellings jumped 6.2%.

image.altText: Hands shaking in the foreground with dancers in the background, at night.

items.synopsis: The Deaf Indigenous Dance Group aims to inspire hard-of-hearing children from remote communities around Australia to feel the music and embrace the freedom of dance.

title.children: Feeling the music: How a deaf dance group is bringing together remote communities

image.altText: A tennis player with hands on hips argues with a chair umpire at Wimbledon.

items.synopsis: Tears, injuries, upsets and a harsh interpretation of the laws of tennis cause controversy at The All England Club, while Novak Djokovic just keeps on winning.
